0.text: We’re thrilled to announce the 15th annual VIZBI meeting on ‘Visualizing Biological Data’ (https://vizbi.org). Each year, we invite 21 world-leading experts in data visualization and the life sciences. Every meeting has been amazing, and this year is shaping up to be our best ever! We're at a fantastic location at the University of Cambridge, UK. Join us in-person or online!

2.text:
Even a visit to Boston Dynamics headquarters in Massachusetts brought some parallels to energy management 🔋

Whether it’s a Spot robot, an EV charging station, or a Battery Energy Storage System, the operational backbone is built on the similar principles: high-frequency telemetry, remote control, and predictive oversight.

Just as Spot robots are equipped with thermal cameras to monitor heat levels at production sites, BESS operators rely on thermal sensor monitoring to ensure stable operation and prevent dangerous overheating that accelerates battery life degradation.

It’s inspiring to see how Boston Dynamics approaches remote robot fleet management with the Orbit platform — a model that could also improve the way we think about managing distributed energy assets.

Thanks for the demo and great discussion.
Special thanks tofor arranging Boston Dynamics visit.

Thanks for organizing this trip:






Delegation members:,,,,

9.text:
Follow along here as we feature 
hashtag
#Researchers @ UMass Boston and ways discovery, innovation, and impact are happening on our 
hashtag
#Boston campus and beyond! 
++++
Featured Researcher:, Graduated in
in December 2024

“As an undergraduate researcher at UMass Boston, I have developed AmpliVision, a software for automated readout of a Ampli tests which can be trained to recognize the
pattern of different diseases using few mobile phone pictures.

Ampli is a reconfigurable version of lateral flow assays (LFAs), or rapid tests, where test components are broken down into modular, LEGO-like blocks that can be snapped together in different configurations, allowing for flexible and adaptable
.

Automated Ampli tests have the potential to make a significant public health impact on infectious disease control as widely distributed user-centric diagnostics. I aim to make these tests more accessible for widespread use, particularly for visually impaired users, who may be unable to perceive color differences.

I am particularly passionate about creating resourceful, accessible solutions that maximize widespread technology—such as using a smartphone for diagnostics instead of requiring new physical devices. This approach ensures that innovations in disease detection can reach more people without adding unnecessary costs or barriers.

My work would not have been possible without the guidance of my advisors, Professors Kimberly Hamad-Schifferli and Daniel Haehn, as well as PhD candidate Josselyn Mata, whose insights have been instrumental in shaping my research. It would have also not been possible without UMass Boston's excellent undergraduate research opportunities, including U54 (UMass Boston–Dana-Farber/Harvard Cancer Center partnership), the IDS Fellowship, and BSSF (Beacon Student Success Fellowship), which provide invaluable support for student-led research.

Additionally, it was an honor to present my research at the
Conference in Pittsburgh, where I had the incredible opportunity to meet and share my work with a broader scientific community and was humbled to receive an award for my presentation.”

In the photo: Matheus,,, and(left to right), at the Annual Research Symposium at
presenting early developments of AmpliVision as of Summer 2024.

13.text:
VISUALIZING BIOLOGICAL DATA. Join us 8-11 April online or in-person at the University of Cambridge for VIZBI 2025, the 15th international meeting on Visualising Biological Data. Pre-register now at.

DATAVIS ADVANCES. Highlights include keynotes on cutting-edge DataVis methods from Marc Streit ('Explainable AI') and Tobias Isenberg ('In­ter­ac­tive data ex­plo­ra­tion in 2D & 3D'), and a masterclass from Drew Berry ('Visual storytelling')..

LIFE SCIENCE BREAKTHROUGHS. The VIZBI workshop features inspiring talks from 21 world-leading researchers on visualizations transforming how life scientists understand data..

DATAVIS MASTERCLASS. The meeting also features a one-day intensive DataVis training event from world-leading practitioners..

WHY ATTEND? You can present your work and engage with a unique community of leading practitioners, including scientists, data visualization specialists, medical illustrators, graphic designers, and industry leaders..

SECURE YOUR SPOT. You can ensure your Early Bird discount, and your slot as poster presenter by pre-registering at#pre-register.

25.text:
"We have to use our privilege in ways that empower those who lack it." - bell hooks

I feel very blessed to receive two awards this semester - here the announcement from CS Department Chair:

Daniel got this year's CSM Excellence in Undergraduate Education Award . Since his arrival at UMB, Daniel has energized the department and made a huge difference to our students through his teaching and event organizing. Congratulations as well!

Being an award collector, Daniel also just received a Center for Innovative Teaching (CIT) Award for Inclusive Pedagogies at UMass Boston. The CIT's reasoning for this award describes Daniel's achievements very well:

"Your dedication to fostering inclusivity and diversity within the classroom environment, along with your innovative approaches to decolonizing pedagogies and universal teaching designs, has truly set you apart. Your commitment to creating welcoming and supportive atmospheres for students from all backgrounds, incorporating diverse voices and perspectives into the curriculum, and actively engaging students in the learning process has not gone unnoticed. Your efforts have not only enhanced accessibility and engagement for all students but have also contributed to positive student feedback, learning outcomes, and retention rates. Also, your leadership qualities in advocating for inclusive teaching practices and fostering collaboration among faculty, staff, and students have been commendable."

Thank you so much!! Here is my speech:

29.text: It's so easy, even I can do it. :) A co-worker just published a wonderfully clear tutorial on how to convert a sequence of C++ ITK filters into a web assembly module that can be called from python, RUST, javascript, R, and many other languages. With support for multi-threading and complex data structures, web assembly is going to absolutely change how scientific computing is delivered for desktop, web, client-server apps, and whatever comes next...

35.text:
Full video essay now on YouTube: https://lnkd.in/gt2dEUNc

Buzzfeed recently published a now deleted article on what AI thinks Barbies would look like from different countries around the world.

The results contained extreme forms of representational bias - including colourist and racist depictions, which is something that AI image generators are often prone to doing.

With AI image generators like MidJourney, Stable Diffusion, and Dall-E gaining huge popularity, it’s important that we are vigilant about the forms of bias that these technologies can fuel.

38.text:
Are machines ready for graphical perception? 

CNNs are able to perform really well on visualization tasks such as measuring angles, estimating volumes, and understanding textures. However, slight modifications such as changing the width of a simple line throws them off.

We replicate Cleveland and McGill's seminal experiments using CNNs and measure cross-network generalizability. Video/Code/Data at
